source: # This notebook imports the Skaneateles data, splits it into training and validation sets, and runs the data on a number of models.

import numpy as np
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Read in data from csv into pandas dataframe
data = pd.read_csv("DATAforMODEL.csv")

data # Data has date and coorinates of location, HAB column (1 for yes there was a bloom, 0 for no ther was not
     # a bloom), NDWI value, and precip value (daily average)

# Spliting data into training and validation subsets - 80% for training data

from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
train, test = train_test_split(data, test_size=0.2)

train

# set style for upcoming graph

sns.set_style('dark')
import matplotlib as mpl
mpl.style.use(['https://gist.githubusercontent.com/BrendanMartin/01e71bb9550774e2ccff3af7574c0020/raw/6fa9681c7d0232d34c9271de9be150e584e606fe/lds_default.mplstyle'])
mpl.rcParams.update({"figure.figsize": (8,6), "axes.titlepad": 22.0})

source:
# print the target variable, target names, and frequency of each unique value

print('Target variables  : ', train['HAB'])

(unique, counts) = np.unique(train['HAB'], return_counts=True)

print('Unique values of the target variable', unique)
print('Counts of the target variable :', counts)

#plot a bar chart to see the target variable

sns.barplot(x=unique, y=counts)
plt.title('Target variable counts in dataset')
plt.show()

# 0 = no bloom, 1 = bloom

source:
# Define explonatory variables and target variable

predictors = ['NDWI', 'PRECIP']    
predictand = ['HAB']

X = train[predictors]
X

source: Y = train[predictand]
Y

# Apply normalization operation for numerical stability

from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
standardizer = StandardScaler()
X = standardizer.fit_transform(X)

# create an empty dictionary, initialize each model, then store it by name in the dictionary

models = {}

# Logistic Regression
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
models['Logistic Regression'] = LogisticRegression()

# Support Vector Machines
from sklearn.svm import LinearSVC
models['Support Vector Machines'] = LinearSVC()

# Decision Trees
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier
models['Decision Trees'] = DecisionTreeClassifier()

# Random Forest
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
models['Random Forest'] = RandomForestClassifier()

# Naive Bayes
from sklearn.naive_bayes import GaussianNB
models['Naive Bayes'] = GaussianNB()

# K-Nearest Neighbors
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier
models['K-Nearest Neighbor'] = KNeighborsClassifier()

outputs.name: stderr

source:
# loop over each one, fit it, make predictions, calculate metrics, and store each result in a dictionary

from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score, precision_score, recall_score

accuracy, precision, recall = {}, {}, {}

for key in models.keys():
    
    # Fit the classifier model
    models[key].fit(X, Y)
    
    # Prediction 
    predictions = models[key].predict(X)
    
    # Calculate Accuracy, Precision and Recall Metrics
    accuracy[key] = accuracy_score(predictions, Y)
    precision[key] = precision_score(predictions, Y)
    recall[key] = recall_score(predictions, Y)

source:
# use the pandas library to view the data as a table

df_model = pd.DataFrame(index=models.keys(), columns=['Accuracy', 'Precision', 'Recall'])
df_model['Accuracy'] = accuracy.values()
df_model['Precision'] = precision.values()
df_model['Recall'] = recall.values()

df_model

# bar chart to compare the classifiers performance

ax  = df_model.plot.bar(rot=45)
ax.legend(ncol= len(models.keys()), bbox_to_anchor=(0, 1), loc='lower left', prop={'size': 14})
plt.tight_layout()
# Running Decision Tree Model since it was the most accurate:

# Fit model to the training data

model = DecisionTreeClassifier()
model.fit(X, Y)

source:
# Make predictions on the training data
predictions = model.predict(X)

# Calculate the accuracy score by comparing the actual values and predicted values

from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix

cm = confusion_matrix(Y, predictions)

TN, FP, FN, TP = confusion_matrix(Y, predictions).ravel()

print('True Positive(TP)  = ', TP)
print('False Positive(FP) = ', FP)
print('True Negative(TN)  = ', TN)
print('False Negative(FN) = ', FN)

accuracy =  (TP+TN) /(TP+FP+TN+FN)

print('Accuracy of the binary classification = {:0.3f}'.format(accuracy))
# Running model again on validation data to compare:

# subsetting validation data into predicors and predictands

X2 = test[predictors]
Y2 = test[predictand]

source:
# running decision tree model and evaluating accuracy

standardizer = StandardScaler()
X2 = standardizer.fit_transform(X2)

model = DecisionTreeClassifier()
model.fit(X2, Y2)

predictions = model.predict(X2)

cm = confusion_matrix(Y2, predictions)

TN, FP, FN, TP = confusion_matrix(Y2, predictions).ravel()

print('True Positive(TP)  = ', TP)
print('False Positive(FP) = ', FP)
print('True Negative(TN)  = ', TN)
print('False Negative(FN) = ', FN)

accuracy =  (TP+TN) /(TP+FP+TN+FN)

print('Accuracy of the binary classification = {:0.3f}'.format(accuracy))
